results.title: Sign Up for the Science Times Newsletter
results.abstract: Every week, we’ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.

results.title: Lightning Strikes California With Unusual Frequency This Summer
results.abstract: Weather patterns channeling moisture into the state have led to an abundance of lightning strikes that have ignited hundreds of wildfires.

multimedia.caption: Lighting strikes to the West over the Oxnard plain as seen from Thousand Oaks, CA.
multimedia.copyright: Al Seib/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Image

results.title: Energy Secretary Attacks Offshore Wind and Dismisses Climate Change
results.abstract: Chris Wright, who travels to Europe next week to promote American gas, called climate change “not incredibly important.”

multimedia.caption: Chris Wright, the energy secretary, also said, “We don’t want to be in the race for the most expensive electricity in the world.”
multimedia.copyright: Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images

results.title: Federal Report on Drinking Is Withdrawn
results.abstract: The upcoming U.S. Dietary Guidelines will instead be influenced by a competing study, favored by industry, which found that moderate alcohol consumption was healthy.
org_facet: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine

multimedia.caption: The report that has been sidelined is one of several that have upended a long-dominant narrative about alcohol that suggested that moderate drinking was not harmful and might even have health benefits.
multimedia.copyright: Colin Clark for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: The report that has been sidelined is one of several that have upended a long-dominant narrative about alcohol that suggested that moderate drinking was not harmful and might even have health benefits.

results.title: Debate Flares Over an Unproven Link Between Tylenol and Autism
results.abstract: Studies over the last decade of acetaminophen use in pregnancy — including a recent scientific review — have yielded mixed results but have not found a causal connection.

multimedia.caption: A new scientific review has been swept up in a larger, politically fraught debate over the causes of autism.
multimedia.copyright: Gary Cameron/Reuters

multimedia.caption: A new scientific review has been swept up in a larger, politically fraught debate over the causes of autism.
multimedia.copyright: Gary Cameron/Reuters

results.title: A. James Hudspeth, Who Unlocked Mysteries Behind Hearing, Dies at 79
results.abstract: He was pivotal in discovering how sound waves are converted into signals that the brain can perceive as a whisper, a symphony or a thunderclap.

multimedia.caption: Dr. A. James Hudspeth in 2019 in a lab containing zebrafish tanks. His work involved exploring how such nonmammalian animals can regain hearing.
multimedia.copyright: Mario Morgado, via the Rockefeller University

multimedia.caption: Dr. A. James Hudspeth in 2019 in a lab containing zebrafish tanks. His work involved exploring how such nonmammalian animals can regain hearing.
multimedia.copyright: Mario Morgado, via the Rockefeller University

results.title: Two Valuable Satellites Are in ‘Perfect Health.’ They May Be Scrapped.
results.abstract: The Trump administration wants to switch off and possibly destroy the climate-monitoring technology.

multimedia.caption: Some of the satellite technology at risk of being defunded is attached to the International Space Station.

results.title: Ebola Outbreak Is Declared in Province of Congo
results.abstract: Health officials have recorded 28 suspected cases and 15 fatalities so far in the latest outbreak of the deadly virus, which has claimed thousands of lives in previous outbreaks in the Central African country.

multimedia.caption: Receiving a vaccination against Ebola in 2019 in the Democratic Republic of Congo. A team, joined by World Health Organization personnel, has been deployed to monitor the latest outbreak.
multimedia.copyright: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

results.title: Humans Are Altering the Seas. Here’s What the Future Ocean Might Look Like.
results.abstract: Some marine ecosystems could soon be unrecognizable, according to new research. We mapped the possibilities.
results.byline: By Delger Erdenesanaa and Mira Rojanasakul

multimedia.copyright: The New York Times
The New York Times

results.title: Orsted Sues Trump Administration in Fight to Restart Its Blocked Wind Farm
results.abstract: The Danish company behind Revolution Wind, a $6 billion project off Rhode Island, said the federal government had unlawfully halted work on the wind farm.
results.byline: By Brad Plumer and Karen Zraick
org_facet: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement

results.title: Whistle-Blower Complaints Detail Tension Over Vaccines at N.I.H.
results.abstract: Two former agency leaders said the administration’s “hostility” toward vaccines had spread to the agency’s top ranks.
org_facet: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

multimedia.caption: The National Institutes of Health headquarters in Bethesda, Md. Watching a resistance to vaccines take root even at the at the N.I.H., a redoubt of vaccine research, alarmed the two scientists.
multimedia.copyright: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times

results.title: Health Care Costs for Workers Begin to Climb
results.abstract: A survey shows employers expect a sharp increase in benefit costs for next year, and many will want workers to shoulder more of the burden.

multimedia.caption: Rising health care costs expected in the next year worry some experts, who fear some employees will skip or delay medical care because they can no longer afford it.
multimedia.copyright: Arin Yoon/Reuters

results.title: A Defiant Kennedy Defends Vaccine Changes and C.D.C. Shake-Up
results.abstract: A three-hour hearing before the Senate Finance Committee revealed that the health secretary was on uncertain ground even with some Republicans who voted to confirm him.
results.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Megan Mineiro
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: Health Secretary Robert Kennedy Jr. at Thursday’s hearing, which descended into a free-for-all, in part over Mr. Kennedy’s approach to vaccination, the turmoil at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and especially his decision last week to fire Susan Monarez, the C.D.C. director.
multimedia.copyright: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Health Secretary Robert Kennedy Jr. at Thursday’s hearing, which descended into a free-for-all, in part over Mr. Kennedy’s approach to vaccination, the turmoil at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and especially his decision last week to fire Susan Monarez, the C.D.C. director.
multimedia.copyright: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Health Secretary Robert Kennedy Jr. at Thursday’s hearing, which descended into a free-for-all, in part over Mr. Kennedy’s approach to vaccination, the turmoil at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and especially his decision last week to fire Susan Monarez, the C.D.C. director.
multimedia.copyright: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

results.title: 3 Psychiatric Tools That Could Boost the Brain’s Natural Healing
results.abstract: They work for depression and P.T.S.D. Could they also help the brain repair itself after a neurologic catastrophe?

multimedia.caption: Promising contenders for neurorehabilitation include transcranial magnetic stimulation, antidepressant pills and psychedelics, therapies that are better known for treating like depression, P.T.S.D. and obsessive-compulsive disorder.
multimedia.copyright: Puwadol Jaturawutthichai/Alamy

multimedia.caption: Promising contenders for neurorehabilitation include transcranial magnetic stimulation, antidepressant pills and psychedelics, therapies that are better known for treating like depression, P.T.S.D. and obsessive-compulsive disorder.

results.title: Inside Trump’s Unorthodox Climate Attacks in Courts Nationwide
results.abstract: The administration is cranking up efforts to kill state laws and legal cases that would force fossil-fuel companies to pay for climate damage.

multimedia.caption: Flood damage in Vermont in 2023. The administration has sued the state over its climate superfund law.
multimedia.copyright: Hilary Swift for The New York Times

results.title: Kennedy to Add New Members to Vaccine Advisory Panel
results.abstract: The health secretary fired the original committee members in June, replacing them with some who have been critical of vaccines.

org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

results.title: Watchdog Warns Trump’s Cuts at FEMA Pose a ‘Major Challenge’
results.abstract: The country lacks the ability to address multiple disasters happening at once, the Government Accountability Office said.

results.title: F.D.A. Official Overruled Scientists on Wide Access to Covid Shots
results.abstract: The agency’s staff scientists pointed out how Covid was still unpredictable and posed a threat to toddlers, but the official decided to restrict shots only to children with risk factors.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: Dr. Vinay Prasad disagreed with staff at the F.D.A., wanting to narrow Covid vaccination approvals to people younger than 65 who have health conditions that put them at risk for severe disease.
multimedia.copyright: Emily Elconin/Reuters

results.title: States Go Their Own (and Contradictory) Ways on Vaccine Policy
results.abstract: California, Oregon and Washington said they would work together to review scientific data, saying the C.D.C. could no longer be trusted. But Florida said it would abolish all vaccine mandates.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: Federal policies on vaccines have been changing rapidly since Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a vaccine skeptic, became secretary of Health and Human Services.

results.title: President Trump Is Alive. The Internet Was Convinced Otherwise.
results.abstract: In the world of presidential health, distrust and speculation run so rampant that even Mr. Trump’s online assurance that he was fine was immediately explained away as part of a cover-up.

multimedia.caption: President Trump was seen looking at his cellphone as he departed his golf club in Virginia on Sunday.

results.title: Trump Wants Proof That Covid Vaccines Work. It’s Easy to Find.
results.abstract: In a post on Truth Social, the president suggested that the C.D.C. was being “ripped apart” over a question that was answered long ago.
results.byline: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Carl Zimmer
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: Five years after the pandemic began, most people in the U.S. have some immunity to Covid from vaccination, infection, or both.

results.title: Reduced Screening May Have Led to Rise in Advanced Prostate Cancer Diagnoses
results.abstract: Changes in screening recommendations over a decade ago may have inadvertently resulted in later diagnosis of the most common cancer in men, a new study has found.

United States Preventive Services Task Force

results.title: Scientists May Have Identified a Culprit Behind Declining Amazon Rains
results.abstract: Deforestation is playing a greater role than researchers expected, according to a new study.

multimedia.caption: A deforested area in Acre State, in western Brazil, in April. For the first half of 2025, officials reported a 27 percent increase in tree loss nationwide compared with the same period last year.
multimedia.copyright: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times

results.title: With ‘Weather Hunters,’ Al Roker Finally Brings the Rainbow Home
results.abstract: Inspired by a funny request from his children years ago, his new series teaches young viewers about clouds, thunder and the ingredients of a rainbow.

multimedia.caption: Al Roker, who has long anchored the weather report on the NBC morning show “Today,” has now created an educational animated series for PBS Kids.
